awd_titl_txt: Annual New York State Regional Graduate Mathematics Conference
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides participant support to the Annual New York State Regional Graduate Mathematics Conference (ANYSRGMC) for the next three years. The 2019 conference is held at Syracuse University on Saturday, March 23, 2019.  This conference presented an opportunity for graduate students in New York State and surrounding regions to come together, share current research, and interact with other graduate students in a similar phase of their academic career.  Opportunities to speak at conferences are an essential part of training future mathematicians.  Unlike other graduate student mathematics conferences in the region, at the ANYSRGMC graduate students in all areas of mathematics have an opportunity to present their research.  In many cases this is the first time a graduate student will speak at a conference, giving them a valuable opportunity to learn how to structure and deliver a talk.  In addition, given the broad range of topics covered, graduate students have the opportunity to learn about other research going on in the region, as well be exposed to areas of mathematics that they are less familiar.  NSF funding increased access to this conference, giving graduate students with fewer financial resources available to them an opportunity to take advantage of this conference.
 
The ANYSRGMC is a one-day conference, the majority of which consists of 30 minute graduate student talks given in parallel sessions.  There are two invited guest speakers, an opening address on Saturday morning and a Keynote address Saturday afternoon.  The two speakers are typically prominent mathematicians in two distinct areas of mathematics who can speak to the diverse interests of the graduate students at Syracuse University and surrounding regions.  In addition to hearing interesting mathematics, students have the opportunity to meet and learn from successful mathematicians outside of their home universities.  Breaks between the talks gave graduate students a chance to interact with each other, potentially leading to new collaborations.  The website for the conference is at http://mgo.syr.edu/conferences-talks/conference/upcoming-conferences .

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This grant supports an annual conference hosted at Syracuse University, aimed at graduate students in mathematics and related disciplines: the Annual New York State Regional Graduate Mathematics Conference (ANYSRGMC). This conference is the longest-running conference in the nation organized completely by graduate students, and given that the conference is aimed at graduate students, this fact sets us apart from other conferences of a similar flavor – who more appropriate to organize a conference for current graduate students than current graduate students? Funding for the ANYSRGMC provided through this award has been crucial to maintaining the excellence and smooth execution of the six editions of the ANYSRGMC: conference edition numbers 44-49. This includes meetings in Spring 2020 and 2021 that were forced on-line due to the covid pandemic.  In the last three years the conference has met in person with increasing attendance each year. 

The goals of the ANYSRGMC include exposing graduate students to exciting and developing areas of mathematics, potential collaborators, and potential mentors, as well as giving graduate students an environment to present their research to their peers. The execution of these goals results in both the advancement of knowledge within mathematics and the professional development of up-and-coming researchers.

 From across the United States (as well as a handful of other countries) graduate students in a variety of areas within mathematics and related disciplines come to SU to give presentations on their research and learn from each other and two keynote speakers. The keynote speakers over the past six  iterations have been professors in multiple mathematical areas from universities across the United States, as well as one from a Canadian institution. The conferences have been total successes, with attendees engaging with each other and the keynote speakers throughout the day, as well as at a dinner in which the conferences conclude. Attendance numbers ranged between 35 to 60-or-so participants, and the significant majority of participants presented a 20-minute research talk.  The conference ran over either one or two days, depending on the year.

The ANYSRGMC is also funded by the mathematics department at SU, the Graduate Student Organization (GSO) at SU, and the AMS. This NSF award went toward travel and hotel expenses for student participants, and hotel expenses for keynote speakers. We, the organizers of the ANYSRGMC, pride ourselves on being able to offer graduate students this experience at little-to-no cost to them, and the NSF has been invaluable in our ability to do this. We seek to include in the conference, as both participants and keynote speakers,  members of the mathematical communities from underrepresented backgrounds, and we have had success in this goal over the past six years.

 


Last Modified: 08/01/2024
Modified by: William Wylie
